text: What is the biggest risk when you hold a large leveraged position on a crypto exchange?
answers: Someone stealing your wallet private key
Government taking your funds
Getting liquidated if the price moves against you
High network fees

text: In crypto trading, a "whale" usually means:
answers: Someone or a group that owns a huge amount of a cryptocurrency
A market maker on big exchanges
A trader who only uses charts
A developer who can change the project's code

text: What does "slippage" mean when trading crypto?
answers: Price slowly dropping in a bear market
The difference between the price you expected and the price you actually got
Fees paid to liquidity providers
Delay in confirming your order on the blockchain

text: Which on-chain metric is commonly used to check Bitcoin's network health and possible price direction?
answers: How much Bitcoin flows in or out of exchanges
Google search trends
Daily mentions on Twitter
Only the trading volume on centralized exchanges

text: When Bitcoin perpetual futures show a negative funding rate for many weeks in a row, plus very high open interest, it usually means:
answers: The market sentiment is neutral with no clear direction
It's just temporary distortion before the next contract rollover
Longs are dominant and confident enough to pay shorts
A short squeeze is about to happen because too many shorts are leveraged

text: What is a stop-loss order mainly used for in crypto trading?
answers: Entering a trade only when price breaks a resistance level
Buying more during price dips
Automatically taking profits at a higher price
Limiting your losses by closing the trade at a set price

text: Which strategy means buying crypto cheaper on one exchange and selling it higher on another at the same time?
answers: Dollar-cost averaging
Arbitrage
Scalping
HODLing

text: A positive funding rate in perpetual futures usually shows that:
answers: The market is perfectly balanced
A contract expiration is coming soon
Shorts are paying longs
Longs are paying shorts

text: On crypto lending platforms, some platforms lend out the same user-deposited coins multiple times to make extra profit. What is this risky practice called?
answers: Proving reserves publicly on-chain
Re-lending the same deposits over and over
Withdrawing user funds
Converting everything to stablecoins automatically

text: An experienced trader sees Bitcoin's Realized Price going up quickly while the spot price stays flat. This usually means:
answers: Short-term holders are taking profits aggressively
Only whales are quietly accumulating
New buyers are coming in at higher prices, which could support the price later
Long-term holders are selling at a loss

text: Why do traders use a limit order instead of a market order in crypto?
answers: To buy or sell instantly at any price
To automatically follow the price movement
To choose the exact price they're happy to buy or sell at
To hide how big their order is

text: In crypto, "FOMO" (Fear Of Missing Out) usually causes traders to:
answers: Buy near local tops or all-time highs
Slowly reduce their position size
Move coins to cold storage
Sell at market bottoms

text: What is a key risk of holding fiat-pegged stablecoins?
answers: Only smart contract bugs
The stablecoin losing its 1:1 peg to the fiat currency
Mining difficulty changes
A 51% attack on the blockchain

text: Long squeezes and short squeezes in crypto futures are mainly caused by:
answers: Only regulatory news
Sudden high transaction fees
A chain of liquidations pushing price sharply in one direction
Exchange downtime for maintenance

text: When you have a leveraged long position in a very volatile altcoin, what should you watch most closely in real time to avoid getting liquidated in a flash crash?
answers: Total open interest on the exchange
24-hour trading volume compared to market cap
Just your unrealized profit/loss percentage
Maintenance margin level and how close your margin ratio is to the liquidation price
